ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss secondary to bacterial meningitis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Sudden onset of profound hearing loss following confirmed Streptococcus suis meningitis infection.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To determine the degree and configuration of hearing loss.
To assess middle ear function (declined by patient due to intolerance).
To verify hearing aid fitting (could not be performed as patient resisted probe insertion).
Aided sound-field thresholds to assess functional gain with current hearing aids.
To evaluate speech perception capabilities with and without visual cues.
Radiologic evaluation (CT) to check for cochlear ossification.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Assessments confirmed bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss with negligible speech perception benefits from high-power hearing aids (aided thresholds 55-65 dB HL, 0-3% auditory-only speech scores). CT imaging 1 month post-meningitis showed no ossification, indicating the patient was a candidate for urgent cochlear implantation.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss; no responses at audiometer limits for most frequencies.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Hong Kong Speech Perception Test: Auditory-only scores were negligible (0% everyday sentences, 3% keywords). Visual cues improved everyday sentence recognition to 41%.

tests.name: Other
tests.result_summary: Aided sound-field thresholds with Phonak Una SP AZ aids were 55-65 dB HL (500-4000 Hz), providing insufficient gain.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Declined by patient due to inability to tolerate probe insertion.

tests.name: Other
tests.result_summary: CT scan performed 1 month post-meningitis revealed no significant cochlear abnormality (no ossification).

proposed_items: Post-operative cochlear implant programming and mapping
counseling_actions: Counsel on the urgency of implantation due to the high risk of cochlear ossification (osteoneogenesis) following meningitis
Discuss realistic expectations regarding cochlear implant outcomes
Emphasize the importance of motivation and family support for rehabilitation

red_flags_present: Sudden onset profound sensorineural hearing loss
History of bacterial meningitis (risk of cochlear ossification)

escalation.rationale_short: Urgent referral is required to proceed with implantation before potential cochlear ossification prevents electrode insertion.

follow_up_plan.objective: To activate and map the cochlear implants and monitor speech perception progress.

expected_outcome: Sound-field audiometry with bilateral CIs: Thresholds obtained within the speech banana (approx. 30-40 dB HL) across 500-4000 Hz.
Hong Kong Speech Perception Test (3 years post-op): Everyday Sentence Recognition (syllable scoring) 100% in auditory-only mode.
Hong Kong Speech Perception Test (3 years post-op): Open-set Sentence Recognition (keyword scoring) 67% in auditory-only mode.
Hong Kong Speech Perception Test (3 years post-op): Open-set Sentence Recognition (syllable scoring) 79% in auditory-only mode.
Patient is able to perceive open-set sentences without visual cues and communicate verbally in quiet and most noisy situations.
